MONITORING AND REPORTING OBLIGATIONS

Page

Table of Contents

How to avoid tipping off

 

A number of strategies can be adopted to lower a business's risk of engaging in tipping off:

 

•

Provide customers with clear communication about procedures.

•

Provide support to, and closely supervise, employees dealing with suspected and high-risk clients.

•

In instances where clients' accounts may need to be frozen or terminated, seek advice and assistance from appropriate law enforcement bodies.

•

Put into place both secure physical storage protection for suspicious matter report ("SMR") information and also secure internal reporting avenues for SMR information.

•

Do not try to treat every SMR case in a uniform manner. Each case needs to be adapted to its individual circumstances.

•

Obtain legal advice where necessary

 

Source: AML Magazine March 2007

 

When dealing with suspicious matters and reporting obligations, be careful not to commit the offence of tipping off. This occurs when your organisation:

has formed a suspicion about a matter and you disclose to someone (or have them assume) that your organisation is suspicious about the matter

has made a report to AUSTRAC and you disclose to someone that AUSTRAC has been informed about a suspicious matter

has made a report to AUSTRAC and you disclose to someone information from which they could reasonably infer that a report has been made to AUSTRAC about a suspicious matter

Certain exceptions apply, including certain disclosures to lawyers and accountants and members of designated business groups.

 

Penalties

Tipping off can attract heavy penalties, including imprisonment for two years and/or a $21,600 fine.
